messages.content:
You are an AI assistant specialized in analyzing web projects developed using PHP and the Laravel 11.x (laravel/framework ^11.28) framework. I need to generate an OpenAPI Specification for a web project based on its backend source code. In `app/Http/Controllers/UserController.php`, I found that `App\\Http\\Controllers\\UserController::update` is implemented to process HTTP requests to the path `/users/{user}`. To determine the full path with the correct prefix and the acceptable HTTP methods, I found the necessary information in other files.

I'll provide you with the contents of all related files, and your task is to determine and output:

- The full HTTP request path for the endpoint, which must begin with a forward slash (/) and have path parameters wrapped in curly braces ({}).
- Whether all HTTP methods are acceptable, this will override the results for other HTTP methods.
- Whether the HEAD method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the POST method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the OPTIONS method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the TRACE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the GET method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PUT method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the DELETE method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.
- Whether the PATCH method is acceptable, based on the code, not on experiential assumptions.

You also need to provide an explanation of your results.

message.content:
Full path
- /users/{user}

All methods acceptable?
- No

Acceptable HTTP methods (based on the route definitions / code)
- HEAD: Yes
- POST: No
- OPTIONS: No
- TRACE: No
- GET: Yes
- PUT: No
- DELETE: No
- PATCH: No

Explanation
- In routes/web.php the routes for users are declared as Route::resource('users', UserController::class)->only('show');. The resource 'show' action maps to the single route GET /users/{user} (the controller method UserController::show).
- There is no route registration for the update or edit resource actions (update would be PUT/PATCH /users/{user}), so although UserController::update exists, no PUT or PATCH route is registered for /users/{user}.
- Laravel exposes HEAD requests for GET routes, so the GET route for /users/{user} also accepts HEAD.
- No route is registered that would accept POST, DELETE, OPTIONS, TRACE, or any-other methods for /users/{user}, and there is no Route::any or global catch-all in the provided files that would make "all methods" true.
